docs.lead_paragraph: Government officials said yesterday that they had decided to expand the number of Medicare patients who qualify to receive an expensive medical device that is implanted in the chest to help protect against fatal heart rhythms. But the decision to expand coverage was far less than the makers of the pager-sized devices, called defibrillators, had been seeking.

headline.main: U.S. to Back Heart Device In More Cases

docs.abstract: Federal Government will expand number of Medicare patients permitted to receive defibrillators, device implanted in chest and designed to protect against fatal heart rhythms; 45,000 Mediare patients currently receive devices each year, and under latest decision 10,000 more will be added; defibrillators cost $25,000 each, and operation along with follow-up care can come to $40,000 per patient; total cost to Medicare is expected to increase by as much as $400 million over current level of $1 billion (M)
docs.snippet: Government officials said yesterday that they had decided to expand the number of Medicare patients who qualify to receive an expensive medical device that is implanted in the chest to help protect against fatal heart rhythms.    But the decision to...

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury has indicted the chief executive of a California hospital owned by a subsidiary of the Tenet Corporation, the for-profit hospital chain that has recently drawn intense regulatory scrutiny. In the indictment, which was filed on Thursday in San Diego, federal officials accuse Barry Weinbaum, the chief executive of Alvarado Hospital Medical Center, of making illegal payments to doctors to induce them to refer patients to the hospital. Last December, the company said federal agents had raided the hospital, seeking information about physician recruitment and agreements with some doctors.

headline.main: Chief of Tenet-Owned Hospital Is Indicted

docs.abstract: US grand jury indicts Barry Weinbaum, head of Tenet Corp-owned Alvarado Medical Center, on charges of making illegal payments to doctors to gain patient referrals to hospital; indictment is latest in series of regulatory and legal problems faced by Tenet, whose share price has fallen dramatically since 2002; company is being investigated for its Medicare billing practices as well as possible unnecessary surgeries performed at another of its California hospitals (M)
docs.snippet: A federal grand jury has indicted the chief executive of a California hospital owned by a subsidiary of the Tenet Corporation, the for-profit hospital chain that has recently drawn intense regulatory scrutiny.    In the indictment, which was filed on...

docs.lead_paragraph: Teachers on strike at a northwestern New Jersey school district defied a judge's order yesterday, refusing to work for the second day in a row and forcing the district to close school today. John A. Toleno, superintendent of the North Warren Regional School District, in Warren County, said he made the decision after a state judge said teachers would be fined $250 per day if they did not show up for work. The fines begin after the district can show the members of the teachers' union, in writing, the judge's decision. ''I couldn't possibly do that by tomorrow morning, so I was forced to cancel school for tomorrow,'' Mr. Toleno said last night.

headline.main: School Is Canceled as Strike Enters Third Day

docs.abstract: Teachers on strike in Warren County, NJ, defy judge's order to work for second day in row; force district to close school (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Several influential senators announced today that they had reached a bipartisan agreement on legislation to provide prescription drug coverage to the elderly, through the traditional government-run Medicare program and through newer private health plans. The deal was forged by Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee, and Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the senior Democrat on the panel.

headline.main: Senators Reach Agreement On Drug Plan for the Elderly

docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee strikes bipartisan deal, forged by Sen Charles E Grassley and Sen Max Baucus, on legislation to provide comprehensive prescription drug coverage to elderly; proposal would offer choice between traditional government-run Medicare program and new private health plans (M)
docs.snippet: Several influential senators announced today that they had reached a bipartisan agreement on legislation to provide prescription drug coverage to the elderly, through the traditional government-run Medicare program and through newer private health...

docs.lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of senators, led by a conservative Republican, said today that they would push legislation to give consumers swifter access to low-cost copies of brand-name prescription drugs. At the same time, Senate Republicans worked out the final details of a separate bill that would add prescription drug benefits to Medicare, the federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled.

headline.main: 2 Drug Bills Advance to Ease Access to Generics and to Add Medicare Benefits

docs.abstract: Bipartisan group of senators led by Sens Judd Gregg and Charles E Schumer say they will push bill to give consumers swifter access to low-cost copies of brand-name prescription drugs; bill involves curbing efforts by drug companies to extend patents; Senate Republicans complete work on bill to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare; bill would encourage greater use of private health plans in Medicare, but offer identical drug benefits under traditional fee-for-service Medicare plans; Bush administration welcomes developments (M)
docs.snippet: A bipartisan group of senators, led by a conservative Republican, said today that they would push legislation to give consumers swifter access to low-cost copies of brand-name prescription drugs.    At the same time, Senate Republicans worked out the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Seven months ago, I made the decision to hasten the end of my wife's life. Susan lay in an irreversible coma and had not been fed for 10 days; she was being kept alive solely by fluids. An old family friend stopped by with advice that no one in the medical profession had been able to offer. ''You need to stop giving your wife liquid,'' he said.
docs.abstract: Tom Nesi Op-Ed article questions value of new drugs that may help terminal cancer patients to live few more months; cites conditions in which patient lives and emotional and financial costs as key issues; cites toll taken by his wife's battle with brain cancer; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Undeterred by the prospect of higher taxes, New York State voters overwhelmingly approved increases in school spending, according to election results released yesterday. Ninety-four percent of the nearly 700 school districts that put their budgets before the voters on Tuesday won approval for them. The passage rate is one of the highest on record, stunning many school officials who had expected far greater reluctance from a public already facing higher state and local taxes.

headline.main: 94% of School Budgets Pass, Most of Them More Expensive

docs.abstract: Ninety-four percent of nearly 700 school districts that put their budgets before voters on June 3 win approval for increases in school spending; school budgets will go up by average 4.1 percent in coming academic year, all at time when state's contribution to education has shrunk (M)
docs.snippet: Undeterred by the prospect of higher taxes, New York State voters overwhelmingly approved increases in school spending, according to election results released yesterday.     Ninety-four percent of the nearly 700 school districts that put their...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Novartis, one of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies, set out to give away a revolutionary cancer drug to people around the world who could not otherwise afford it, the company promised that no patient who needed the medicine would go without it. It was an incredibly ambitious pledge. Often, drug companies donate in bulk to public health systems to combat epidemic diseases like AIDS or malaria. Novartis, however, set out to build a system that would evaluate the health and finances of individual cancer patients scattered around the globe. Those who qualified would get Glivec, a capsule that combats certain types of leukemia and stomach tumors, at no cost. Experts estimate that as many as 600,000 patients -- most of them in poor countries -- could benefit.

headline.main: Drug Maker's Vow to Donate Cancer Medicine Falls Short

docs.abstract: Novartis promised two years ago to give away revolutionary cancer drug Glivec to people around world who could not afford it, but pharmaceutical company's ambitious pledge has been only partially fulfilled; 2,000 patients in United States have gotten free medication, but effort has fallen short elsewhere, with drug being given to just 1,500 patients outside US; critics say Novartis is using donations as marketing strategy with goal of building Glivec sales to $1 billion annually; in India, for example, Novartis halted program after government let local companies eat into profits by selling generic version of drug; in wealthier countries like South Korea, Hong Kong and New Zealand, Novartis has encouraged patients who received free drugs to become advocates, pressing public health systems to buy Glivec; Novartis chose tiny nonprofit group Max Foundation to run international patient assistance program after established charities turned down job, but there have been complaints over effectiveness of foundation's functioning; photos (M)
docs.snippet: When Novartis, one of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies, set out to give away a revolutionary cancer drug to people around the world who could not otherwise afford it, the company promised that no patient who needed the medicine would go...

byline.original: By STEPHANIE STROM and MATT FLEISCHER-BLACK; Saritha Rai in Bangalore, India, contributed to this report

docs.lead_paragraph: WellPoint Health Networks, one of the nation's largest health insurers, announced last night that it had agreed to acquire the Cobalt Corporation, the publicly traded holding company of Blue Cross and Blue Shield United of Wisconsin, for $906 million in cash and stock. The deal will add Cobalt's 800,000 members to WellPoint's national network of 13.5 million people. The acquisition of Cobalt -- worth $20.50 a share -- fills out WellPoint's network in the Midwest, raising its total membership in the region to 3.5 million.

headline.main: WellPoint in Deal to Acquire Health Insurer in Wisconsin

docs.abstract: WellPoint Health Networks agrees to acquire Cobalt Corp, holding company of rival health insurer Blue Cross and Blue Shield United of Wisconsin, for $906 million in cash and stock (M)
docs.snippet: WellPoint Health Networks, one of the nation's largest health insurers, announced last night that it had agreed to acquire the Cobalt Corporation, the publicly traded holding company of Blue Cross and Blue Shield United of Wisconsin, for $906 million...

keywords.value: BLUE CROSS AND BLUE SHIELD UNITED OF WISCONSIN

byline.original: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and MILT FREUDENHEIM

docs.lead_paragraph: Alabama's new Republican governor, Bob Riley, styles himself after Ronald Reagan, complete with a pompadour and campaign photos that show him on horseback. Philosophically, too, he is an avowed Reaganite who says he never voted for a tax increase in six years in Congress and was once named its most conservative member. Yet this same Mr. Riley has stunned his state and his party, and risked his political future, by calling for Alabama's largest tax increase ever: $1.3 billion, or 22 percent of the taxes the state now collects.

headline.main: G.O.P. Chief's Idea for Raising Alabama: Taxes

docs.abstract: Gov Bob Riley, conservative Republican, has stunned Alabama and his party and risked his political future by calling for $1.3 billion tax increase, 22 percent boost and state's largest tax rise ever; takes on own political base, big corporations, farmers, timberland owners and rural, antigovernment constituency, with plan to redistribute money from wealthy to working poor; is getting most of what he asked from special legislative session; will then put entire proposal before people in single referendum, giving self just 90 days to sell plan to famously anti-tax population; he comments, interview; graphs of state taxes and spending; photo (M)
